audio_caption: The audio clip starts with speech, a male speaker says "And we're back now with Congressman Ron Paul who joins us from Fairbanks Alaska, where it is the middle of the night" followed by a summary of the political contest in Alaska and then addressing the Congressman thanking him for joining and asking him where he thought he could win on Tuesday night. Another male speaker begins to respond.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing his measurement of winning. He speaks confidently about winning most of the delegates and mentions specific states where he believes he will win. The same male speaker transitions to addressing another person as Congressman, stating he has a serious question and asking it respectfully.

The clip begins with a male speaker asking, "Are you, uh, in this to the end?" and questioning the purpose behind the campaign, speaking in a conversational tone. Another male voice responds, stating he's answered the question "a few times" and questioning why it has to be an either-or situation. He emphasizes that winning is the best way to promote a cause, citing his congressional wins and ability to get his district to understand "true liberty." He concludes by saying that winning elections has been "very beneficial to promoting that cause" and ends by saying "it doesn't bother me."

The clip features a male speaker addressing a question, expressing belief in his chances but acknowledging they are slim. He highlights the unpredictable nature of the world and the potential for changing circumstances, internationally and monetarily. His tone is thoughtful and considered. He clarifies that it shouldn't be an "either-or" situation.

The clip starts with a male speaker, speaking in a conversational tone. He describes the other speaker's main purpose as making a point, underlying the libertarian point of view and strengthening libertarians rather than winning the nomination.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that he said something different and clarifies that both things are "mutual." The same male speaker then follows this up with "Uh," indicating a slight pause or hesitation in his speech. The speaker is speaking in a conversational and somewhat clarifying tone.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing his frustrations with political motivations, questioning why politicians seem so focused on "gaining power" over all else. He says that when he finds someone focused on real issues, he sees an individual who is "translating this into political action that is successful." The speaker is impassioned, his tone reflecting a certain amount of frustration and hopefulness. Throughout, a radio broadcast style background noise is present.

The audio clip features two male speakers, one of whom is interviewing the other. The interviewer's tone is inquisitive as he asks if the interviewee was surprised by Rick Santorum's statement suggesting a collaboration with Mitt Romney. The interviewee does not respond within the provided audio.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker who's commenting on others suggesting his actions are aimed at creating a scenario where "Romney might ask your son, Senator Rand Paul," to be his running mate, and asks for reaction.  A second male responds in a conversational tone, suggesting someone is attempting to "concoct a conspiracy" and labels it media-driven, saying that media sources were saying "is there a deal?" he rejects the idea. He believes the other person's action is driven by inability to find other issues to attack him on.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing Rush Limbaugh's apology for calling a young woman from Georgetown a "prostitute," due to her testimony in favor of government healthcare plans paying for birth control pills, and questioning what the listener thinks about the apology and whether it bothers them when campaigns wander into social issues. The speaker speaks in a conversational and slightly critical tone. Another male speaker responds in a thoughtful tone, not considering the issue strictly as a social one.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing someone who should have apologized for crude language, suggesting they were concerned about their bottom line due to advertisers pulling out. He then shifts to discussing Santorum's views on birth control and his own support as an OB doctor. The speech is conversational and flows into the end.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing the philosophical and political importance of whether the government has a mandate to tell insurance companies what to give, specifically mentioning free birth control pills. He questions whether individuals who do not need or object to birth control should have to pay for others' access to it. The speaker expresses confusion and disagreement with this concept, questioning the fairness of forcing individuals to pay for OB care if they are not planning to have a baby. The speaking tone is inquisitive and somewhat critical.

The clip starts with a male speaker passionately discussing "total destruction of the marketplace" and the mandate and "obsession with Obama on mandating", suggesting that Republicans aren't much better either. He criticizes the idea of being "forced to pay for birth control pills" and "forced people who are strongly right to life to pay money" for abortions, mentioning that Planned Parenthood does that. He adds an ironic tidbit, that Santorum actually funded Planned Parenthood but "pretends to be the champion of social values." He calls him a "fake conservative". He ends by saying "all right."
The audio clip starts with a male speaker saying, "Well, uh, Congressman, it's always good to talk to you," in a friendly tone, and then thanking someone for "getting up so early."
